content:
![img-6.jpeg](images/image_5_6.jpeg)
FIGURE 5.4

# Solution

Potential energy of the configuration arises due to the potential energy of one dipole (say,  $\mathbf{Q}$ ) in the magnetic field due to other (P). Use the result that the field due to  $\mathbf{P}$  is given by the expression [Eqs. (5.4) and (5.5)]:

$$
\mathbf {B} _ {\mathrm {P}} = - \frac {\mu_ {0}}{4 \pi} \frac {\mathbf {m} _ {\mathrm {P}}}{r ^ {3}} \quad (\text {o n t h e n o r m a l b i s e c t o r})
$$

$$
\mathbf {B} _ {\mathrm {P}} = \frac {\mu_ {0} 2}{4 \pi} \frac {\mathbf {m} _ {\mathrm {P}}}{r ^ {3}} \quad (\text {o n t h e a x i s})
$$

where  $\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{P}}$  is the magnetic moment of the dipole P.
summary: This is a lecture slide about potential energy arising from the interaction between one dipole and another in the presence of magnetic fields.
hypothetical_questions: What happens to the magnetic field when a dipole is introduced?
How does the magnetic moment of a dipole affect its interaction with a magnetic field?
Can the configuration of one dipole effect the potential energy of other dipoles nearby?
